segment.source: Create a Windows 10 reference image (Windows 10)
segment.target: Create a Windows 10 reference image (Windows 10)

segment.source: Creating a reference image is important because that image serves as the foundation for the devices in your organization.
segment.target: Creating a reference image is important because that image serves as the foundation for the devices in your organization.

segment.source: Create a Windows 10 reference image
segment.target: Create a Windows 10 reference image

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Creating a reference image is important because that image serves as the foundation for the devices in your organization.
segment.target: Creating a reference image is important because that image serves as the foundation for the devices in your organization.

segment.source: In this topic, you will learn how to create a Windows 10 reference image using the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) 2013 Update 2.
segment.target: In this topic, you will learn how to create a Windows 10 reference image using the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) 2013 Update 2.

segment.source: You will create a deployment share, configure rules and settings, and import all the applications and operating system files required to build a Windows 10 reference image.
segment.target: You will create a deployment share, configure rules and settings, and import all the applications and operating system files required to build a Windows 10 reference image.

segment.source: After completing the steps outlined in this topic, you will have a Windows 10 reference image that can be used in your deployment solution.
segment.target: After completing the steps outlined in this topic, you will have a Windows 10 reference image that can be used in your deployment solution.

segment.source: For the purposes of this topic, we will use four machines: DC01, MDT01, HV01, and PC0001.
segment.target: For the purposes of this topic, we will use four machines: DC01, MDT01, HV01, and PC0001.

segment.source: DC01 is a domain controller, PC0001 is a Windows 10 Enterprise x64 client, and MDT01 is a Windows Server 2012 R2 standard server.
segment.target: DC01 is a domain controller, PC0001 is a Windows 10 Enterprise x64 client, and MDT01 is a Windows Server 2012 R2 standard server.

segment.source: HV01 is a Hyper-V host server, but HV01 could be replaced by PC0001 as long as PC0001 has enough memory and is capable of running Hyper-V.
segment.target: HV01 is a Hyper-V host server, but HV01 could be replaced by PC0001 as long as PC0001 has enough memory and is capable of running Hyper-V.

segment.source: MDT01, HV01, and PC0001 are members of the domain contoso.com for the fictitious Contoso Corporation.
segment.target: MDT01, HV01, and PC0001 are members of the domain contoso.com for the fictitious Contoso Corporation.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: For important details about the setup for the steps outlined in this article, please see Deploy Windows 10 with the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit.
segment.target: For important details about the setup for the steps outlined in this article, please see Deploy Windows 10 with the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit.

segment.target: figure 1

segment.target: Figure 1.

segment.source: The machines used in this topic.
segment.target: The machines used in this topic.

segment.source: The reference image
segment.target: The reference image

segment.source: The reference image described in this documentation is designed primarily for deployment to physical machines.
segment.target: The reference image described in this documentation is designed primarily for deployment to physical machines.

segment.source: However, the reference image is created on a virtual platform, before being automatically run through the System Preparation (Sysprep) tool process and captured to a Windows Imaging (WIM) file.
segment.target: However, the reference image is created on a virtual platform, before being automatically run through the System Preparation (Sysprep) tool process and captured to a Windows Imaging (WIM) file.

segment.source: The reasons for creating the reference image on a virtual platform are the following:
segment.target: The reasons for creating the reference image on a virtual platform are the following:

segment.source: You reduce development time and can use snapshots to test different configurations quickly.
segment.target: You reduce development time and can use snapshots to test different configurations quickly.

segment.source: You rule out hardware issues.
segment.target: You rule out hardware issues.

segment.source: You simply get the best possible image, and if you have a problem, it's not likely to be hardware related.
segment.target: You simply get the best possible image, and if you have a problem, it's not likely to be hardware related.

segment.source: It ensures that you won't have unwanted applications that could be installed as part of a driver install but not removed by the Sysprep process.
segment.target: It ensures that you won't have unwanted applications that could be installed as part of a driver install but not removed by the Sysprep process.

segment.source: It's easy to move between lab, test, and production.
segment.target: It's easy to move between lab, test, and production.

segment.source: Set up the MDT build lab deployment share
segment.target: Set up the MDT build lab deployment share

segment.source: With Windows 10, there is no hard requirement to create reference images; however, to reduce the time needed for deployment, you may want to create a reference image that contains a few base applications as well as all of the latest updates.
segment.target: With Windows 10, there is no hard requirement to create reference images; however, to reduce the time needed for deployment, you may want to create a reference image that contains a few base applications as well as all of the latest updates.

segment.source: This section will show you how to create and configure the MDT Build Lab deployment share to create a Windows 10 reference image.
segment.target: This section will show you how to create and configure the MDT Build Lab deployment share to create a Windows 10 reference image.

segment.source: Because reference images will be deployed only to virtual machines during the creation process and have specific settings (rules), you should always create a separate deployment share specifically for this process.
segment.target: Because reference images will be deployed only to virtual machines during the creation process and have specific settings (rules), you should always create a separate deployment share specifically for this process.

segment.target: Create the MDT build lab deployment share

segment.source: On MDT01, log on as Administrator in the CONTOSO domain using a password of P@ssw0rd.
segment.target: On MDT01, log on as Administrator in the CONTOSO domain using a password of P@ssw0rd.

segment.source: Using the Deployment Workbench, right-click Deployment Shares and select New Deployment Share.
segment.target: Using the Deployment Workbench, right-click Deployment Shares and select New Deployment Share.

segment.target: Use the following settings for the New Deployment Share Wizard:

segment.target: Deployment share path: E:MDTBuildLab

segment.source: Share name: MDTBuildLab$
segment.target: Share name: MDTBuildLab$

segment.source: Deployment share description: MDT Build Lab
segment.target: Deployment share description: MDT Build Lab

segment.source: default
segment.target: default

segment.source: Verify that you can access the MDT01MDTBuildLab$ share.
segment.target: Verify that you can access the MDT01MDTBuildLab$ share.

segment.source: Add the setup files
segment.target: Add the setup files

segment.source: This section will show you how to populate the MDT 2013 Update 2 deployment share with the Windows 10 operating system source files, commonly referred to as setup files, which will be used to create a reference image.
segment.target: This section will show you how to populate the MDT 2013 Update 2 deployment share with the Windows 10 operating system source files, commonly referred to as setup files, which will be used to create a reference image.

segment.source: Setup files are used during the reference image creation process and are the foundation for the reference image.
segment.target: Setup files are used during the reference image creation process and are the foundation for the reference image.

segment.source: Add the Windows 10 installation files
segment.target: Add the Windows 10 installation files

segment.source: MDT 2013 supports adding both full source Windows 10 DVDs (ISOs) and custom images that you have created.
segment.target: MDT 2013 supports adding both full source Windows 10 DVDs (ISOs) and custom images that you have created.

segment.source: In this case, you create a reference image, so you add the full source setup files from Microsoft.
segment.target: In this case, you create a reference image, so you add the full source setup files from Microsoft.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Due to the Windows limits on path length, we are purposely keeping the operating system destination directory short, using the folder name W10EX64RTM rather than a more descriptive name like Windows 10 Enterprise x64 RTM.
segment.target: Due to the Windows limits on path length, we are purposely keeping the operating system destination directory short, using the folder name W10EX64RTM rather than a more descriptive name like Windows 10 Enterprise x64 RTM.

segment.source: Add Windows 10 Enterprise x64 (full source)
segment.target: Add Windows 10 Enterprise x64 (full source)

segment.source: In these steps we assume that you have copied the content of a Windows 10 Enterprise x64 ISO to the E:DownloadsWindows 10 Enterprise x64 folder.
segment.target: In these steps we assume that you have copied the content of a Windows 10 Enterprise x64 ISO to the E:DownloadsWindows 10 Enterprise x64 folder.

segment.source: On MDT01, log on as CONTOSOAdministrator.
segment.target: On MDT01, log on as CONTOSOAdministrator.

segment.source: Using the Deployment Workbench, expand the Deployment Shares node, and then expand MDT Build Lab.
segment.target: Using the Deployment Workbench, expand the Deployment Shares node, and then expand MDT Build Lab.

segment.source: Right-click the Operating Systems node, and create a new folder named Windows 10.
segment.target: Right-click the Operating Systems node, and create a new folder named Windows 10.

segment.source: Expand the Operating Systems node, right-click the Windows 10 folder, and select Import Operating System.
segment.target: Expand the Operating Systems node, right-click the Windows 10 folder, and select Import Operating System.

segment.source: Use the following settings for the Import Operating System Wizard:
segment.target: Use the following settings for the Import Operating System Wizard:

segment.source: Full set of source files
segment.target: Full set of source files

segment.source: Source directory: E:DownloadsWindows 10 Enterprise x64
segment.target: Source directory: E:DownloadsWindows 10 Enterprise x64

segment.source: Destination directory name: W10EX64RTM
segment.target: Destination directory name: W10EX64RTM

segment.source: After adding the operating system, in the Operating Systems / Windows 10 folder, double-click the added operating system name in the Operating System node and change the name to the following: Windows 10 Enterprise x64 RTM Default Image
segment.target: After adding the operating system, in the Operating Systems / Windows 10 folder, double-click the added operating system name in the Operating System node and change the name to the following: Windows 10 Enterprise x64 RTM Default Image

segment.source: Add applications
segment.target: Add applications

segment.source: Before you create an MDT task sequence, you need to add all of the applications and other sample scripts to the MDT Build Lab share.
segment.target: Before you create an MDT task sequence, you need to add all of the applications and other sample scripts to the MDT Build Lab share.

segment.source: The steps in this section use a strict naming standard for your MDT applications.
segment.target: The steps in this section use a strict naming standard for your MDT applications.

segment.source: You add the "Install - " prefix for typical application installations that run a setup installer of some kind, and you use the "Configure - " prefix when an application configures a setting in the operating system.
segment.target: You add the "Install - " prefix for typical application installations that run a setup installer of some kind, and you use the "Configure - " prefix when an application configures a setting in the operating system.

segment.source: You also add an " - x86", " - x64", or "- x86-x64" suffix to indicate the application's architecture (some applications have installers for both architectures).
segment.target: You also add an " - x86", " - x64", or "- x86-x64" suffix to indicate the application's architecture (some applications have installers for both architectures).

segment.source: Using a script naming standard is always recommended when using MDT as it helps maintain order and consistency.
segment.target: Using a script naming standard is always recommended when using MDT as it helps maintain order and consistency.

segment.source: By storing configuration items as MDT applications, it is easy to move these objects between various solutions, or between test and production environments.
segment.target: By storing configuration items as MDT applications, it is easy to move these objects between various solutions, or between test and production environments.

segment.target: In this topic's step-by-step sections, you will add the following applications:

segment.source: Create the install: Microsoft Office Professional Plus 2013 x86
segment.target: Create the install: Microsoft Office Professional Plus 2013 x86

segment.source: You can customize Office 2013.
segment.target: You can customize Office 2013.

segment.source: In the volume license versions of Office 2013, there is an Office Customization Tool you can use to customize the Office installation.
segment.target: In the volume license versions of Office 2013, there is an Office Customization Tool you can use to customize the Office installation.

segment.source: In these steps we assume you have copied the Office 2013 installation files to the E:DownloadsOffice2013 folder.
segment.target: In these steps we assume you have copied the Office 2013 installation files to the E:DownloadsOffice2013 folder.

segment.source: Add the Microsoft Office Professional Plus 2013 x86 installation files
segment.target: Add the Microsoft Office Professional Plus 2013 x86 installation files

segment.source: After adding the Microsoft Office Professional Plus 2013 x86 application, you then automate its setup by running the Office Customization Tool.
segment.target: After adding the Microsoft Office Professional Plus 2013 x86 application, you then automate its setup by running the Office Customization Tool.

segment.source: In fact, MDT 2013 detects that you added the Office Professional Plus 2013 x86 application and creates a shortcut for doing this.
segment.target: In fact, MDT 2013 detects that you added the Office Professional Plus 2013 x86 application and creates a shortcut for doing this.

segment.source: You also can customize the Office installation using a Config.xml file.
segment.target: You also can customize the Office installation using a Config.xml file.

segment.source: But we recommend that you use the Office Customization Tool as described in the following steps, as it provides a much richer way of controlling Office 2013 settings.
segment.target: But we recommend that you use the Office Customization Tool as described in the following steps, as it provides a much richer way of controlling Office 2013 settings.

segment.source: Using the Deployment Workbench in the MDT Build Lab deployment share, expand the Applications / Microsoft node, and double-click Install - Microsoft Office 2013 Pro Plus x86.
segment.target: Using the Deployment Workbench in the MDT Build Lab deployment share, expand the Applications / Microsoft node, and double-click Install - Microsoft Office 2013 Pro Plus x86.

segment.source: In the Office Products tab, click Office Customization Tool, and click OK in the Information dialog box.
segment.target: In the Office Products tab, click Office Customization Tool, and click OK in the Information dialog box.

segment.target: figure 5

segment.source: Figure 5.
segment.target: Figure 5.

segment.target: The Install - Microsoft Office 2013 Pro Plus - x86 application properties.

segment.target: Note

segment.source: If you don't see the Office Products tab, verify that you are using a volume license version of Office.
segment.target: If you don't see the Office Products tab, verify that you are using a volume license version of Office.

segment.source: If you are deploying Office 365, you need to download the Admin folder from Microsoft.
segment.target: If you are deploying Office 365, you need to download the Admin folder from Microsoft.

segment.source: In the Office Customization Tool dialog box, select the Create a new Setup customization file for the following product option, select the Microsoft Office Professional Plus 2013 (32-bit) product, and click OK.
segment.target: In the Office Customization Tool dialog box, select the Create a new Setup customization file for the following product option, select the Microsoft Office Professional Plus 2013 (32-bit) product, and click OK.

segment.target: Select Display level: None

segment.source: Modify Setup properties
segment.target: Modify Setup properties

segment.source: Add the SETUPREBOOT property and set the value to Never.
segment.target: Add the SETUPREBOOT property and set the value to Never.

segment.source: Modify user settings
segment.target: Modify user settings

segment.source: In the Microsoft Office 2013 node, expand Privacy, select Trust Center, and enable the Disable Opt-in Wizard on first run setting.
segment.target: In the Microsoft Office 2013 node, expand Privacy, select Trust Center, and enable the Disable Opt-in Wizard on first run setting.

segment.source: From the File menu, select Save, and save the configuration as 0Office2013ProPlusx86.msp in the E:MDTBuildLabApplicationsInstall - Microsoft Office 2013 Pro Plus - x86Updates folder.
segment.target: From the File menu, select Save, and save the configuration as 0Office2013ProPlusx86.msp in the E:MDTBuildLabApplicationsInstall - Microsoft Office 2013 Pro Plus - x86Updates folder.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The reason for naming the file with a 0 (zero) at the beginning is that the Updates folder also handles Microsoft Office updates, and they are installed in alphabetical order.
segment.target: The reason for naming the file with a 0 (zero) at the beginning is that the Updates folder also handles Microsoft Office updates, and they are installed in alphabetical order.

segment.source: The Office 2013 setup works best if the customization file is installed before any updates.
segment.target: The Office 2013 setup works best if the customization file is installed before any updates.

segment.source: Close the Office Customization Tool, click Yes in the dialog box, and in the Install - Microsoft Office 2013 Pro Plus - x86 Properties window, click OK.
segment.target: Close the Office Customization Tool, click Yes in the dialog box, and in the Install - Microsoft Office 2013 Pro Plus - x86 Properties window, click OK.

segment.source: Create the reference image task sequence
segment.target: Create the reference image task sequence

segment.source: In order to build and capture your Windows 10 reference image for deployment using MDT, you will create a task sequence.
segment.target: In order to build and capture your Windows 10 reference image for deployment using MDT, you will create a task sequence.

segment.source: The task sequence will reference the operating system and applications that you previously imported into the MDT Build Lab deployment share to build a Windows 10 reference image.
segment.target: The task sequence will reference the operating system and applications that you previously imported into the MDT Build Lab deployment share to build a Windows 10 reference image.

segment.source: After creating the task sequence, you configure it to enable patching against the Windows Server Update Services (WSUS) server.
segment.target: After creating the task sequence, you configure it to enable patching against the Windows Server Update Services (WSUS) server.

segment.source: The Task Sequence Windows Update action supports getting updates directly from Microsoft Update, but you get more stable patching if you use a local WSUS server.
segment.target: The Task Sequence Windows Update action supports getting updates directly from Microsoft Update, but you get more stable patching if you use a local WSUS server.

segment.source: WSUS also allows for an easy process of approving the patches that you are deploying.
segment.target: WSUS also allows for an easy process of approving the patches that you are deploying.

segment.source: Drivers and the reference image
segment.target: Drivers and the reference image

segment.source: Because we use modern virtual platforms for creating our reference images, we don’t need to worry about drivers when creating reference images for Windows 10.
segment.target: Because we use modern virtual platforms for creating our reference images, we don’t need to worry about drivers when creating reference images for Windows 10.

segment.source: We use Hyper-V in our environment, and Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) already has all the needed drivers built-in for Hyper-V.
segment.target: We use Hyper-V in our environment, and Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) already has all the needed drivers built-in for Hyper-V.

segment.source: Optional configuration: Add a suspend action
segment.target: Optional configuration: Add a suspend action

segment.source: The goal when creating a reference image is of course to automate everything.
segment.target: The goal when creating a reference image is of course to automate everything.

segment.source: But sometimes you have a special configuration or application setup that is too time-consuming to automate.
segment.target: But sometimes you have a special configuration or application setup that is too time-consuming to automate.

segment.source: If you need to do some manual configuration, you can add a little-known feature called Lite Touch Installation (LTI) Suspend.
segment.target: If you need to do some manual configuration, you can add a little-known feature called Lite Touch Installation (LTI) Suspend.

segment.source: If you add the LTISuspend.wsf script as a custom action in the task sequence, it will suspend the task sequence until you click the Resume Task Sequence shortcut icon on the desktop.
segment.target: If you add the LTISuspend.wsf script as a custom action in the task sequence, it will suspend the task sequence until you click the Resume Task Sequence shortcut icon on the desktop.

segment.source: In addition to using the LTI Suspend feature for manual configuration or installation, you can also use it simply for verifying a reference image before you allow the task sequence to continue and use Sysprep and capture the virtual machine.
segment.target: In addition to using the LTI Suspend feature for manual configuration or installation, you can also use it simply for verifying a reference image before you allow the task sequence to continue and use Sysprep and capture the virtual machine.

segment.source: Edit the Unattend.xml file for Windows 10 Enterprise
segment.target: Edit the Unattend.xml file for Windows 10 Enterprise

segment.source: When using MDT, you don't need to edit the Unattend.xml file very often because most configurations are taken care of by MDT.
segment.target: When using MDT, you don't need to edit the Unattend.xml file very often because most configurations are taken care of by MDT.

segment.source: However if, for example, you want to configure Internet Explorer 11 behavior, then you can edit the Unattend.xml for this.
segment.target: However if, for example, you want to configure Internet Explorer 11 behavior, then you can edit the Unattend.xml for this.

segment.source: Editing the Unattend.xml for basic Internet Explorer settings is easy, but for more advanced settings, you will want to use Internet Explorer Administration Kit (IEAK).
segment.target: Editing the Unattend.xml for basic Internet Explorer settings is easy, but for more advanced settings, you will want to use Internet Explorer Administration Kit (IEAK).

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: You also can use the Unattend.xml to enable components in Windows 10, like the Telnet Client or Hyper-V client.
segment.target: You also can use the Unattend.xml to enable components in Windows 10, like the Telnet Client or Hyper-V client.

segment.source: Normally we prefer to do this via the Install Roles and Features action, or using Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) command-line tools, because then we can add that as an application, being dynamic, having conditions, and so forth.
segment.target: Normally we prefer to do this via the Install Roles and Features action, or using Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) command-line tools, because then we can add that as an application, being dynamic, having conditions, and so forth.

segment.source: Also, if you are adding packages via Unattend.xml, it is version specific, so Unattend.xml must match the exact version of the operating system you are servicing.
segment.target: Also, if you are adding packages via Unattend.xml, it is version specific, so Unattend.xml must match the exact version of the operating system you are servicing.

segment.source: Configure the MDT deployment share rules
segment.target: Configure the MDT deployment share rules

segment.source: Understanding rules is critical to successfully using MDT.
segment.target: Understanding rules is critical to successfully using MDT.

segment.source: Rules are configured using the Rules tab of the deployment share's properties.
segment.target: Rules are configured using the Rules tab of the deployment share's properties.

segment.source: The Rules tab is essentially a shortcut to edit the CustomSettings.ini file that exists in the E:MDTBuildLabControl folder.
segment.target: The Rules tab is essentially a shortcut to edit the CustomSettings.ini file that exists in the E:MDTBuildLabControl folder.

segment.source: This section discusses how to configure the MDT deployment share rules as part of your Windows 10 Enterprise deployment.
segment.target: This section discusses how to configure the MDT deployment share rules as part of your Windows 10 Enterprise deployment.

segment.source: MDT deployment share rules overview
segment.target: MDT deployment share rules overview

segment.source: In MDT, there are always two rule files: the CustomSettings.ini file and the Bootstrap.ini file.
segment.target: In MDT, there are always two rule files: the CustomSettings.ini file and the Bootstrap.ini file.

segment.source: You can add almost any rule to either; however, the Bootstrap.ini file is copied from the Control folder to the boot image, so the boot image needs to be updated every time you change that file.
segment.target: You can add almost any rule to either; however, the Bootstrap.ini file is copied from the Control folder to the boot image, so the boot image needs to be updated every time you change that file.

segment.source: For that reason, add only a minimal set of rules to Bootstrap.ini, such as which deployment server and share to connect to - the DEPLOYROOT value.
segment.target: For that reason, add only a minimal set of rules to Bootstrap.ini, such as which deployment server and share to connect to - the DEPLOYROOT value.

segment.source: Put the other rules in CustomSettings.ini because that file is updated immediately when you click OK.
segment.target: Put the other rules in CustomSettings.ini because that file is updated immediately when you click OK.

segment.target: By taking the following steps, you will configure the rules for the MDT Build Lab deployment share:

segment.target: Using the Deployment Workbench, right-click the MDT Build Lab deployment share and select Properties.

segment.source: Select the Rules tab and modify using the following information:
segment.target: Select the Rules tab and modify using the following information:

segment.target: For security reasons, you normally don't add the password to the Bootstrap.ini file; however, because this deployment share is for creating reference image builds only, and should not be published to the production network, it is acceptable to do so in this situation.

segment.source: Update the deployment share
segment.target: Update the deployment share

segment.source: After the deployment share has been configured, it needs to be updated.
segment.target: After the deployment share has been configured, it needs to be updated.

segment.source: This is the process when the Windows Windows PE boot images are created.
segment.target: This is the process when the Windows Windows PE boot images are created.

segment.source: Using the Deployment Workbench, right-click the MDT Build Lab deployment share and select Update Deployment Share.
segment.target: Using the Deployment Workbench, right-click the MDT Build Lab deployment share and select Update Deployment Share.

segment.source: Use the default options for the Update Deployment Share Wizard.
segment.target: Use the default options for the Update Deployment Share Wizard.

segment.target: Note

segment.source: The update process will take 5 to 10 minutes.
segment.target: The update process will take 5 to 10 minutes.

segment.source: The rules explained
segment.target: The rules explained

segment.source: Now that the MDT Build Lab deployment share (the share used to create the reference images) has been configured, it is time to explain the various settings used in the Bootstrap.ini and CustomSettings.ini files.
segment.target: Now that the MDT Build Lab deployment share (the share used to create the reference images) has been configured, it is time to explain the various settings used in the Bootstrap.ini and CustomSettings.ini files.

segment.source: The Bootstrap.ini and CustomSettings.ini files work together.
segment.target: The Bootstrap.ini and CustomSettings.ini files work together.

segment.source: The Bootstrap.ini file is always present on the boot image and is read first.
segment.target: The Bootstrap.ini file is always present on the boot image and is read first.

segment.source: The basic purpose for Bootstrap.ini is to provide just enough information for MDT to find the CustomSettings.ini.
segment.target: The basic purpose for Bootstrap.ini is to provide just enough information for MDT to find the CustomSettings.ini.

segment.source: The CustomSettings.ini file is normally stored on the server, in the Deployment shareControl folder, but also can be stored on the media (when using offline media).
segment.target: The CustomSettings.ini file is normally stored on the server, in the Deployment shareControl folder, but also can be stored on the media (when using offline media).

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The settings, or properties, that are used in the rules (CustomSettings.ini and Bootstrap.ini) are listed in the MDT documentation, in the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit Reference / Properties / Property Definition section.
segment.target: The settings, or properties, that are used in the rules (CustomSettings.ini and Bootstrap.ini) are listed in the MDT documentation, in the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit Reference / Properties / Property Definition section.

segment.source: The Bootstrap.ini file
segment.target: The Bootstrap.ini file

segment.source: The Bootstrap.ini file is available via the deployment share's Properties dialog box, or via the E:MDTBuildLabControl folder on MDT01.
segment.target: The Bootstrap.ini file is available via the deployment share's Properties dialog box, or via the E:MDTBuildLabControl folder on MDT01.

segment.source: So, what are these settings?
segment.target: So, what are these settings?

segment.source: Priority.
segment.target: Priority.

segment.source: This determines the order in which different sections are read.
segment.target: This determines the order in which different sections are read.

segment.source: This Bootstrap.ini has only one section, named Default.
segment.target: This Bootstrap.ini has only one section, named Default.

segment.source: DeployRoot.
segment.target: DeployRoot.

segment.source: This is the location of the deployment share.
segment.target: This is the location of the deployment share.

segment.source: Normally, this value is set by MDT, but you need to update the DeployRoot value if you move to another server or other share.
segment.target: Normally, this value is set by MDT, but you need to update the DeployRoot value if you move to another server or other share.

segment.source: If you don't specify a value, the Windows Deployment Wizard prompts you for a location.
segment.target: If you don't specify a value, the Windows Deployment Wizard prompts you for a location.

segment.source: UserDomain, UserID, and UserPassword.
segment.target: UserDomain, UserID, and UserPassword.

segment.source: These values are used for automatic log on to the deployment share.
segment.target: These values are used for automatic log on to the deployment share.

segment.source: Again, if they are not specified, the wizard prompts you.
segment.target: Again, if they are not specified, the wizard prompts you.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Caution is advised.
segment.target: Caution is advised.

segment.source: These values are stored in clear text on the boot image.
segment.target: These values are stored in clear text on the boot image.

segment.source: Use them only for the MDT Build Lab deployment share and not for the MDT Production deployment share that you learn to create in the next topic.
segment.target: Use them only for the MDT Build Lab deployment share and not for the MDT Production deployment share that you learn to create in the next topic.

segment.source: SkipBDDWelcome.
segment.target: SkipBDDWelcome.

segment.source: Even if it is nice to be welcomed every time we start a deployment, we prefer to skip the initial welcome page of the Windows Deployment Wizard.
segment.target: Even if it is nice to be welcomed every time we start a deployment, we prefer to skip the initial welcome page of the Windows Deployment Wizard.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: All properties beginning with "Skip" control only whether to display that pane in the Windows Deployment Wizard.
segment.target: All properties beginning with "Skip" control only whether to display that pane in the Windows Deployment Wizard.

segment.source: Most of the panes also require you to actually set one or more values.
segment.target: Most of the panes also require you to actually set one or more values.

segment.source: The CustomSettings.ini file
segment.target: The CustomSettings.ini file

segment.source: The CustomSettings.ini file, whose content you see on the Rules tab of the deployment share Properties dialog box, contains most of the properties used in the configuration.
segment.target: The CustomSettings.ini file, whose content you see on the Rules tab of the deployment share Properties dialog box, contains most of the properties used in the configuration.

segment.source: Priority.
segment.target: Priority.

segment.source: Has the same function as in Bootstrap.ini.
segment.target: Has the same function as in Bootstrap.ini.

segment.source: Priority determines the order in which different sections are read.
segment.target: Priority determines the order in which different sections are read.

segment.source: This CustomSettings.ini has only one section, named Default.
segment.target: This CustomSettings.ini has only one section, named Default.

segment.source: In general, if you have multiple sections that set the same value, the value from the first section (higher priority) wins.
segment.target: In general, if you have multiple sections that set the same value, the value from the first section (higher priority) wins.

segment.source: The rare exceptions are listed in the ZTIGather.xml file.
segment.target: The rare exceptions are listed in the ZTIGather.xml file.

segment.source: SMSTSORGNAME.
segment.target: SMSTSORGNAME.

segment.source: The organization name displayed in the task sequence progress bar window during deployment.
segment.target: The organization name displayed in the task sequence progress bar window during deployment.

segment.source: UserDataLocation.
segment.target: UserDataLocation.

segment.source: Controls the settings for user state backup.
segment.target: Controls the settings for user state backup.

segment.source: You do not need to use when building and capturing a reference image.
segment.target: You do not need to use when building and capturing a reference image.

segment.source: DoCapture.
segment.target: DoCapture.

segment.source: Configures the task sequence to run the System Preparation (Sysprep) tool and capture the image to a file when the operating system is installed.
segment.target: Configures the task sequence to run the System Preparation (Sysprep) tool and capture the image to a file when the operating system is installed.

segment.source: OSInstall.
segment.target: OSInstall.

segment.source: Must be set to Y or YES (the code actually just looks for the Y character) for the setup to proceed.
segment.target: Must be set to Y or YES (the code actually just looks for the Y character) for the setup to proceed.

segment.source: AdminPassword.
segment.target: AdminPassword.

segment.source: Sets the local Administrator account password.
segment.target: Sets the local Administrator account password.

segment.source: TimeZoneName.
segment.target: TimeZoneName.

segment.source: Establishes the time zone to use.
segment.target: Establishes the time zone to use.

segment.source: Don't confuse this value with TimeZone, which is only for legacy operating systems (Windows 7 and Windows Server 2003).
segment.target: Don't confuse this value with TimeZone, which is only for legacy operating systems (Windows 7 and Windows Server 2003).

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The easiest way to find the current time zone name on a Windows 10 machine is to run tzutil /g in a command prompt.
segment.target: The easiest way to find the current time zone name on a Windows 10 machine is to run tzutil /g in a command prompt.

segment.source: You can also run tzutil /l to get a listing of all available time zone names.
segment.target: You can also run tzutil /l to get a listing of all available time zone names.

segment.source: JoinWorkgroup.
segment.target: JoinWorkgroup.

segment.source: Configures Windows to join a workgroup.
segment.target: Configures Windows to join a workgroup.

segment.source: HideShell.
segment.target: HideShell.

segment.source: Hides the Windows Shell during deployment.
segment.target: Hides the Windows Shell during deployment.

segment.source: This is especially useful for Windows 8.1 deployments in which the deployment wizard will otherwise appear behind the tiles.
segment.target: This is especially useful for Windows 8.1 deployments in which the deployment wizard will otherwise appear behind the tiles.

segment.source: FinishAction.
segment.target: FinishAction.

segment.source: Instructs MDT what to do when the task sequence is complete.
segment.target: Instructs MDT what to do when the task sequence is complete.

segment.source: DoNotCreateExtraPartition.
segment.target: DoNotCreateExtraPartition.

segment.source: Configures the task sequence not to create the extra partition for BitLocker.
segment.target: Configures the task sequence not to create the extra partition for BitLocker.

segment.source: There is no need to do this for your reference image.
segment.target: There is no need to do this for your reference image.

segment.source: WSUSServer.
segment.target: WSUSServer.

segment.source: Specifies which Windows Server Update Services (WSUS) server (and port, if needed) to use during the deployment.
segment.target: Specifies which Windows Server Update Services (WSUS) server (and port, if needed) to use during the deployment.

segment.source: Without this option MDT will use Microsoft Update directly, which will increase deployment time and limit your options of controlling which updates are applied.
segment.target: Without this option MDT will use Microsoft Update directly, which will increase deployment time and limit your options of controlling which updates are applied.

segment.source: SLSHARE.
segment.target: SLSHARE.

segment.source: Instructs MDT to copy the log files to a server share if something goes wrong during deployment, or when a deployment is successfully completed.
segment.target: Instructs MDT to copy the log files to a server share if something goes wrong during deployment, or when a deployment is successfully completed.

segment.source: ApplyGPOPack.
segment.target: ApplyGPOPack.

segment.source: Allows you to deploy local group policies created by Microsoft Security Compliance Manager (SCM).
segment.target: Allows you to deploy local group policies created by Microsoft Security Compliance Manager (SCM).

segment.source: SkipAdminPassword.
segment.target: SkipAdminPassword.

segment.target: Skips the pane that asks for the Administrator password.

segment.source: SkipProductKey.
segment.target: SkipProductKey.

segment.target: Skips the pane that asks for the product key.

segment.source: SkipComputerName.
segment.target: SkipComputerName.

segment.target: Skips the Computer Name pane.

segment.source: SkipDomainMemberShip.
segment.target: SkipDomainMemberShip.

segment.target: Skips the Domain Membership pane.

segment.source: If set to Yes, you need to configure either the JoinWorkgroup value or the JoinDomain, DomainAdmin, DomainAdminDomain, and DomainAdminPassword properties.
segment.target: If set to Yes, you need to configure either the JoinWorkgroup value or the JoinDomain, DomainAdmin, DomainAdminDomain, and DomainAdminPassword properties.

segment.source: SkipUserData.
segment.target: SkipUserData.

segment.target: Skips the pane for user state migration.

segment.source: SkipLocaleSelection.
segment.target: SkipLocaleSelection.

segment.target: Skips the pane for selecting language and keyboard settings.

segment.source: SkipTimeZone.
segment.target: SkipTimeZone.

segment.target: Skips the pane for setting the time zone.

segment.target: Skips the Applications pane.

segment.target: SkipBitLocker.

segment.target: Skips the BitLocker pane.

segment.target: SkipSummary.

segment.target: Skips the initial Windows Deployment Wizard summary pane.

segment.target: Skips the Install Roles and Features pane.

segment.target: Skips the Capture pane.

segment.target: SkipFinalSummary.

segment.target: Skips the final Windows Deployment Wizard summary.

segment.source: Build the Windows 10 reference image
segment.target: Build the Windows 10 reference image

segment.source: Once you have created your task sequence, you are ready to create the Windows 10 reference image.
segment.target: Once you have created your task sequence, you are ready to create the Windows 10 reference image.

segment.source: This will be performed by launching the task sequence from a virtual machine which will then automatically perform the reference image creation and capture process.
segment.target: This will be performed by launching the task sequence from a virtual machine which will then automatically perform the reference image creation and capture process.

segment.source: This steps below outline the process used to boot a virtual machine using an ISO boot image created by MDT, and then execute the reference image task sequence image to create and capture the Windows 10 reference image.
segment.target: This steps below outline the process used to boot a virtual machine using an ISO boot image created by MDT, and then execute the reference image task sequence image to create and capture the Windows 10 reference image.

segment.source: Copy the E:MDTBuildLabBootMDT Build Lab x86.iso on MDT01 to C:ISO on the Hyper-V host.
segment.target: Copy the E:MDTBuildLabBootMDT Build Lab x86.iso on MDT01 to C:ISO on the Hyper-V host.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Remember, in MDT you can use the x86 boot image to deploy both x86 and x64 operating system images.
segment.target: Remember, in MDT you can use the x86 boot image to deploy both x86 and x64 operating system images.

segment.source: That's why you can use the x86 boot image instead of the x64 boot image.
segment.target: That's why you can use the x86 boot image instead of the x64 boot image.

segment.source: Create a virtual machine with the following settings:
segment.target: Create a virtual machine with the following settings:

segment.source: Name: REFW10X64-001
segment.target: Name: REFW10X64-001

segment.source: Location: C:VMs
segment.target: Location: C:VMs

segment.source: Memory: 1024 MB
segment.target: Memory: 1024 MB

segment.source: Network: External (The network that is connected to the same infrastructure as MDT01 is)
segment.target: Network: External (The network that is connected to the same infrastructure as MDT01 is)

segment.source: Hard disk: 60 GB (dynamic disk)
segment.target: Hard disk: 60 GB (dynamic disk)

segment.source: Image file: C:ISOMDT Build Lab x86.iso
segment.target: Image file: C:ISOMDT Build Lab x86.iso

segment.source: Take a snapshot of the REFW10X64-001 virtual machine, and name it Clean with MDT Build Lab x86 ISO.
segment.target: Take a snapshot of the REFW10X64-001 virtual machine, and name it Clean with MDT Build Lab x86 ISO.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Taking a snapshot is useful if you need to restart the process and want to make sure you can start clean.
segment.target: Taking a snapshot is useful if you need to restart the process and want to make sure you can start clean.

segment.source: Start the REFW10X64-001 virtual machine.
segment.target: Start the REFW10X64-001 virtual machine.

segment.source: After booting into Windows PE, complete the Windows Deployment Wizard using the following settings:
segment.target: After booting into Windows PE, complete the Windows Deployment Wizard using the following settings:

segment.source: Select a task sequence to execute on this computer: Windows 10 Enterprise x64 RTM Default Image
segment.target: Select a task sequence to execute on this computer: Windows 10 Enterprise x64 RTM Default Image

segment.source: Specify whether to capture an image: Capture an image of this reference computer
segment.target: Specify whether to capture an image: Capture an image of this reference computer

segment.source: Location: MDT01MDTBuildLab$Captures
segment.target: Location: MDT01MDTBuildLab$Captures

segment.source: File name: REFW10X64-001.wim
segment.target: File name: REFW10X64-001.wim

segment.source: The setup now starts and does the following:
segment.target: The setup now starts and does the following:

segment.source: Installs the Windows 10 Enterprise operating system.
segment.target: Installs the Windows 10 Enterprise operating system.

segment.source: Installs the added applications, roles, and features.
segment.target: Installs the added applications, roles, and features.

segment.source: Updates the operating system via your local Windows Server Update Services (WSUS) server.
segment.target: Updates the operating system via your local Windows Server Update Services (WSUS) server.

segment.source: Stages Windows PE on the local disk.
segment.target: Stages Windows PE on the local disk.

segment.source: Runs System Preparation (Sysprep) and reboots into Windows PE.
segment.target: Runs System Preparation (Sysprep) and reboots into Windows PE.

segment.source: Captures the installation to a Windows Imaging (WIM) file.
segment.target: Captures the installation to a Windows Imaging (WIM) file.

segment.source: Turns off the virtual machine.
segment.target: Turns off the virtual machine.

segment.source: After some time, you will have a Windows 10 Enterprise x64 image that is fully patched and has run through Sysprep, located in the E:MDTBuildLabCaptures folder on your deployment server.
segment.target: After some time, you will have a Windows 10 Enterprise x64 image that is fully patched and has run through Sysprep, located in the E:MDTBuildLabCaptures folder on your deployment server.

segment.source: The file name is REFW10X64-001.wim.
segment.target: The file name is REFW10X64-001.wim.
